trans-unit.source: How to use the Azure Command-Line Tools for Mac and Linux
trans-unit.target: How to use the Azure Command-Line Tools for Mac and Linux

trans-unit.source: This guide describes how to use the Azure Command-Line Tools for Mac and Linux to create and manage services in Azure.
trans-unit.target: This guide describes how to use the Azure Command-Line Tools for Mac and Linux to create and manage services in Azure.

trans-unit.source: The scenarios covered include **installing the tools**, **importing your publishing settings**, **creating and managing Azure Websites**, and **creating and managing Azure Virtual Machines**.
trans-unit.target: The scenarios covered include **installing the tools**, **importing your publishing settings**, **creating and managing Azure Websites**, and **creating and managing Azure Virtual Machines**.

trans-unit.source: For comprehensive reference documentation, see [Azure command-line tool for Mac and Linux Documentation][reference-docs].
trans-unit.target: For comprehensive reference documentation, see [Azure command-line tool for Mac and Linux Documentation][reference-docs].

trans-unit.source: Table of contents
trans-unit.target: Table of contents

trans-unit.target: What are the Azure Command-Line Tools for Mac and Linux

trans-unit.target: How to install the Azure Command-Line Tools for Mac and Linux

trans-unit.target: How to create an Azure account

trans-unit.target: How to create and manage an Azure Web Site

trans-unit.source: What are the Azure Command-Line Tools for Mac and Linux
trans-unit.target: What are the Azure Command-Line Tools for Mac and Linux

trans-unit.source: The Azure Command-Line Tools for Mac and Linux are a set of command-line tools for deploying and managing Azure services.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Command-Line Tools for Mac and Linux are a set of command-line tools for deploying and managing Azure services.

trans-unit.source: The supported tasks include the following:
trans-unit.target: The supported tasks include the following:

trans-unit.source: Import publishing settings.
trans-unit.target: Import publishing settings.

trans-unit.source: Create and manage Azure Websites.
trans-unit.target: Create and manage Azure Websites.

trans-unit.source: Create and manage Azure Virtual Machines.
trans-unit.target: Create and manage Azure Virtual Machines.

trans-unit.source: For a complete list of supported commands, type `azure -help` at the command line after installing the tools, or see the [reference documentation][reference-docs].
trans-unit.target: For a complete list of supported commands, type `azure -help` at the command line after installing the tools, or see the [reference documentation][reference-docs].

trans-unit.source: How to install the Azure Command-Line Tools for Mac and Linux
trans-unit.target: How to install the Azure Command-Line Tools for Mac and Linux

trans-unit.source: The following list contains information for installing the command-line tools, depending on your operating system:
trans-unit.target: The following list contains information for installing the command-line tools, depending on your operating system:

trans-unit.source: **Mac**: Download the [Azure SDK Installer][mac-installer].
trans-unit.target: **Mac**: Download the [Azure SDK Installer][mac-installer].

trans-unit.source: Open the downloaded .pkg file and complete the installation steps as you are prompted.
trans-unit.target: Open the downloaded .pkg file and complete the installation steps as you are prompted.

trans-unit.source: **Linux**: Install the latest version of [Node.js][nodejs-org] (see [Install Node.js via Package Manager][install-node-linux]), then run the following command:
trans-unit.target: **Linux**: Install the latest version of [Node.js][nodejs-org] (see [Install Node.js via Package Manager][install-node-linux]), then run the following command:

trans-unit.source: **Note**: You may need to run this command with elevated privileges:
trans-unit.target: **Note**: You may need to run this command with elevated privileges:

trans-unit.source: **Windows**: Run the Winows installer (.msi file), which is available here: [Azure Command Line Tools][windows-installer].
trans-unit.target: **Windows**: Run the Winows installer (.msi file), which is available here: [Azure Command Line Tools][windows-installer].

trans-unit.source: To test the installation, type `azure` at the command prompt.
trans-unit.target: To test the installation, type `azure` at the command prompt.

trans-unit.source: If the installation was successful, you will see a list of all the available `azure` commands.
trans-unit.target: If the installation was successful, you will see a list of all the available `azure` commands.

trans-unit.source: How to create an Azure account
trans-unit.target: How to create an Azure account

trans-unit.source: To use the Azure Command-Line Tools for Mac and Linux, you will need an Azure account.
trans-unit.target: To use the Azure Command-Line Tools for Mac and Linux, you will need an Azure account.

trans-unit.source: Open a web browser and browse to [http://www.windowsazure.com][windowsazuredotcom] and click **free trial** in the upper right corner.
trans-unit.target: Open a web browser and browse to [http://www.windowsazure.com][windowsazuredotcom] and click **free trial** in the upper right corner.

trans-unit.source: ![Azure Web Site][Azure Web Site]
trans-unit.target: ![Azure Web Site][Azure Web Site]

trans-unit.source: Follow the instructions for creating an account.
trans-unit.target: Follow the instructions for creating an account.

trans-unit.source: How to download and import publish settings
trans-unit.target: How to download and import publish settings

trans-unit.source: To get started, you need to first download and import your publish settings.
trans-unit.target: To get started, you need to first download and import your publish settings.

trans-unit.source: This will allow you to use the tools to create and manage Azure Services.
trans-unit.target: This will allow you to use the tools to create and manage Azure Services.

trans-unit.source: To download your publish settings, use the `account download` command:
trans-unit.target: To download your publish settings, use the `account download` command:

trans-unit.source: This will open your default browser and prompt you to sign in to the Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: This will open your default browser and prompt you to sign in to the Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: After signing in, your `.publishsettings` file will be downloaded.
trans-unit.target: After signing in, your `.publishsettings` file will be downloaded.

trans-unit.source: Make note of where this file is saved.
trans-unit.target: Make note of where this file is saved.

trans-unit.source: Next, import the `.publishsettings` file by running the following command, replacing `{path to .publishsettings file}` with the path to your `.publishsettings` file:
trans-unit.target: Next, import the `.publishsettings` file by running the following command, replacing `{path to .publishsettings file}` with the path to your `.publishsettings` file:

trans-unit.source: You can remove all of the information stored by the import command by using the account clear command:
trans-unit.target: You can remove all of the information stored by the import command by using the account clear command:

trans-unit.source: To see a list of options for `account` commands, use the `-help` option:
trans-unit.target: To see a list of options for `account` commands, use the `-help` option:

trans-unit.source: After importing your publish settings, you should delete the `.publishsettings` file for security reasons.
trans-unit.target: After importing your publish settings, you should delete the `.publishsettings` file for security reasons.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] When you import publish settings, credentials for accessing your Azure subscription are stored inside your `user` folder.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] When you import publish settings, credentials for accessing your Azure subscription are stored inside your `user` folder.

trans-unit.source: Your `user` folder is protected by your operating system.
trans-unit.target: Your `user` folder is protected by your operating system.

trans-unit.source: However, it is recommended that you take additional steps to encrypt your `user` folder.
trans-unit.target: However, it is recommended that you take additional steps to encrypt your `user` folder.

trans-unit.source: You can do so in the following ways:
trans-unit.target: You can do so in the following ways:

trans-unit.source: On Windows, modify the folder properties or use BitLocker.
trans-unit.target: On Windows, modify the folder properties or use BitLocker.

trans-unit.source: On Mac, turn on FileVault for the folder.
trans-unit.target: On Mac, turn on FileVault for the folder.

trans-unit.source: On Ubuntu, use the Encrypted Home directory feature.
trans-unit.target: On Ubuntu, use the Encrypted Home directory feature.

trans-unit.source: Other Linux distributions offer equivalent features.
trans-unit.target: Other Linux distributions offer equivalent features.

trans-unit.source: You are now ready to being creating and managing Azure Websites and Azure Virtual Machines.
trans-unit.target: You are now ready to being creating and managing Azure Websites and Azure Virtual Machines.

trans-unit.source: How to create and manage an Azure Website
trans-unit.target: How to create and manage an Azure Website

trans-unit.source: Create a Website
trans-unit.target: Create a Website

trans-unit.source: To create an Azure website, first create an empty directory called `MySite` and browse into that directory.
trans-unit.target: To create an Azure website, first create an empty directory called `MySite` and browse into that directory.

trans-unit.source: Then, run the following command:
trans-unit.target: Then, run the following command:

trans-unit.source: The output from this command will contain the default URL for the newly created website.
trans-unit.target: The output from this command will contain the default URL for the newly created website.

trans-unit.source: The `--git` option allows you to use git to publish to your website by creating git repositories in both your local application directory and in your website's data center.
trans-unit.target: The `--git` option allows you to use git to publish to your website by creating git repositories in both your local application directory and in your website's data center.

trans-unit.source: Note that if your local folder is already a git repository, the command will add a new remote to the existing repository, pointing to the repository in your website's data center.
trans-unit.target: Note that if your local folder is already a git repository, the command will add a new remote to the existing repository, pointing to the repository in your website's data center.

trans-unit.source: Note that you can execute the `azure site create` command with any of the following options:
trans-unit.target: Note that you can execute the `azure site create` command with any of the following options:

trans-unit.source: `--location [location name]`.
trans-unit.target: `--location [location name]`.

trans-unit.source: This option allows you to specify the location of the data center in which your website is created (e.g. "West US").
trans-unit.target: This option allows you to specify the location of the data center in which your website is created (e.g. "West US").

trans-unit.source: If you omit this option, you will be promted to choose a location.
trans-unit.target: If you omit this option, you will be promted to choose a location.

trans-unit.source: `--hostname [custom host name]`.
trans-unit.target: `--hostname [custom host name]`.

trans-unit.source: This option allows you to specify a custom hostname for your website.
trans-unit.target: This option allows you to specify a custom hostname for your website.

trans-unit.source: You can then add content to your website directory.
trans-unit.target: You can then add content to your website directory.

trans-unit.source: Use the regular git flow (`git add`, `git commit`) to commit your content.
trans-unit.target: Use the regular git flow (`git add`, `git commit`) to commit your content.

trans-unit.source: Use the following git command to push your website content to Azure:
trans-unit.target: Use the following git command to push your website content to Azure:

trans-unit.source: Set up publishing from GitHub
trans-unit.target: Set up publishing from GitHub

trans-unit.source: To set up continuous publishing from a GitHub repository, use the `--GitHub` option when creating a site:
trans-unit.target: To set up continuous publishing from a GitHub repository, use the `--GitHub` option when creating a site:

trans-unit.source: If you have a local clone of a GitHub repository or if you have a repository with a single remote reference to a GitHub repository, this command will automatically publish code in the GitHub repository to your site.
trans-unit.target: If you have a local clone of a GitHub repository or if you have a repository with a single remote reference to a GitHub repository, this command will automatically publish code in the GitHub repository to your site.

trans-unit.source: From then on, any changes pushed to the GitHub repository will automatically be published to your site.
trans-unit.target: From then on, any changes pushed to the GitHub repository will automatically be published to your site.

trans-unit.source: When you set up publishing from GitHub, the default branch used is the master branch.
trans-unit.target: When you set up publishing from GitHub, the default branch used is the master branch.

trans-unit.source: To specify a different branch, execute the following command from your local repository:
trans-unit.target: To specify a different branch, execute the following command from your local repository:

trans-unit.source: Configure app settings
trans-unit.target: Configure app settings

trans-unit.source: App settings are key-value pairs that are available to your application at runtime.
trans-unit.target: App settings are key-value pairs that are available to your application at runtime.

trans-unit.source: When set for an Azure Website, app setting values will override settings with the same key that are defined in your site's Web.config file.
trans-unit.target: When set for an Azure Website, app setting values will override settings with the same key that are defined in your site's Web.config file.

trans-unit.source: For Node.js and PHP applications, app settings are available as environment variables.
trans-unit.target: For Node.js and PHP applications, app settings are available as environment variables.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows you how to set a key-value pair:
trans-unit.target: The following example shows you how to set a key-value pair:

trans-unit.source: To see a list of all key/value pairs, use the following:
trans-unit.target: To see a list of all key/value pairs, use the following:

trans-unit.source: Or if you know the key and want to see the value, you can use:
trans-unit.target: Or if you know the key and want to see the value, you can use:

trans-unit.source: If you want to change the value of an existing key you must first clear the existing key and then re-add it.
trans-unit.target: If you want to change the value of an existing key you must first clear the existing key and then re-add it.

trans-unit.source: The clear command is:
trans-unit.target: The clear command is:

trans-unit.source: List and show sites
trans-unit.target: List and show sites

trans-unit.source: To list your websites, use the following command:
trans-unit.target: To list your websites, use the following command:

trans-unit.source: To get detailed information about a site, use the `site show` command.
trans-unit.target: To get detailed information about a site, use the `site show` command.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows details for `MySite`:
trans-unit.target: The following example shows details for `MySite`:

trans-unit.source: Stop, start, or restart a site
trans-unit.target: Stop, start, or restart a site

trans-unit.source: You can stop, start, or restart a site with the `site stop`, `site start`, or `site restart` commands:
trans-unit.target: You can stop, start, or restart a site with the `site stop`, `site start`, or `site restart` commands:

trans-unit.source: Delete a site
trans-unit.target: Delete a site

trans-unit.source: Finally, you can delete a site with the `site delete` command:
trans-unit.target: Finally, you can delete a site with the `site delete` command:

trans-unit.source: Note that if you are running any of above commands from inside the folder where you ran `site create`, you do not need to specify the site name `MySite` as the last parameter.
trans-unit.target: Note that if you are running any of above commands from inside the folder where you ran `site create`, you do not need to specify the site name `MySite` as the last parameter.

trans-unit.source: To see a complete list of `site` commands, use the `-help` option:
trans-unit.target: To see a complete list of `site` commands, use the `-help` option:

trans-unit.source: How to create and manage an Azure Virtual Machine
trans-unit.target: How to create and manage an Azure Virtual Machine

trans-unit.source: an Azure Virtual Machine is created from a virtual machine image (a .vhd file) that you provide or that is available in the Image Gallery.
trans-unit.target: an Azure Virtual Machine is created from a virtual machine image (a .vhd file) that you provide or that is available in the Image Gallery.

trans-unit.source: To see images that are available, use the `vm image list` command:
trans-unit.target: To see images that are available, use the `vm image list` command:

trans-unit.source: You can provision and start a virtual machine from one of the available images with the `vm create` command.
trans-unit.target: You can provision and start a virtual machine from one of the available images with the `vm create` command.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to create a Linux virtual machine (called `myVM`) from an image in the Image Gallery (CentOS 6.2).
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to create a Linux virtual machine (called `myVM`) from an image in the Image Gallery (CentOS 6.2).

trans-unit.source: The root user name and password for the virtual machine are `myusername` and `Mypassw0rd` respectively.
trans-unit.target: The root user name and password for the virtual machine are `myusername` and `Mypassw0rd` respectively.

trans-unit.source: (Note that the `--location` parameter specifies the data center in which the virtual machine is created.
trans-unit.target: (Note that the `--location` parameter specifies the data center in which the virtual machine is created.

trans-unit.source: If you omit the `--location` parameter, you will be prompted to choose a location.)
trans-unit.target: If you omit the `--location` parameter, you will be prompted to choose a location.)

trans-unit.source: You may consider passing the `--ssh` flag (Linux) or `--rdp` flag (Windows) to `vm create` to enable remote connections to the newly-created virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: You may consider passing the `--ssh` flag (Linux) or `--rdp` flag (Windows) to `vm create` to enable remote connections to the newly-created virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: If you would rather provision a virtual machine from a custom image, you can create an image from a .vhd file with the `vm image create` command, then use the `vm create` command to provision the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: If you would rather provision a virtual machine from a custom image, you can create an image from a .vhd file with the `vm image create` command, then use the `vm create` command to provision the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to create a Linux image (called `myImage`) from a local .vhd file.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to create a Linux image (called `myImage`) from a local .vhd file.

trans-unit.source: (The `--location` parameter specifies the data in which the image is stored.)
trans-unit.target: (The `--location` parameter specifies the data in which the image is stored.)

trans-unit.source: Instead of creating an image from a local .vhd, you can create an image from a .vhd stored in Azure Blob Storage.
trans-unit.target: Instead of creating an image from a local .vhd, you can create an image from a .vhd stored in Azure Blob Storage.

trans-unit.source: You can do this with the `blob-url` parameter:
trans-unit.target: You can do this with the `blob-url` parameter:

trans-unit.source: After creating an image, you can provision a virtual machine from the image by using `vm create`.
trans-unit.target: After creating an image, you can provision a virtual machine from the image by using `vm create`.

trans-unit.source: The command below creates a virtual machine called `myVM` from the image created above (`myImage`).
trans-unit.target: The command below creates a virtual machine called `myVM` from the image created above (`myImage`).

trans-unit.source: After you have provisioned a virtual machine, you may want to create endpoints to allow remote access to your virtual machine (for example).
trans-unit.target: After you have provisioned a virtual machine, you may want to create endpoints to allow remote access to your virtual machine (for example).

trans-unit.source: The following example uses the `vm create endpoint` command to open external port 22 and local port 22 on `myVM`:
trans-unit.target: The following example uses the `vm create endpoint` command to open external port 22 and local port 22 on `myVM`:

trans-unit.source: You can get detailed information about a virtual machine (including IP address, DNS name, and endpoint information) with the `vm show` command:
trans-unit.target: You can get detailed information about a virtual machine (including IP address, DNS name, and endpoint information) with the `vm show` command:

trans-unit.source: To shutdown, start, or restart the virtual machine, use one of the following commands:
trans-unit.target: To shutdown, start, or restart the virtual machine, use one of the following commands:

trans-unit.source: And finally, to delete the VM, use the `vm delete` command:
trans-unit.target: And finally, to delete the VM, use the `vm delete` command:

trans-unit.target: For a complete list of commands for creating and managing virtual machines, use the `-h` option:
